trans-unit.source: Configure a VNet-to-VNet connection | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Configure a VNet-to-VNet connection | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: How to connect Azure virtual networks together in the same or different subscriptions or regions.
trans-unit.target: How to connect Azure virtual networks together in the same or different subscriptions or regions.

trans-unit.source: Configure a VNet-to-VNet connection in the Azure Portal
trans-unit.target: Configure a VNet-to-VNet connection in the Azure Portal

trans-unit.source: This article will walk you through connecting virtual networks together in the classic deployment mode by using a combination of the Azure Portal and PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: This article will walk you through connecting virtual networks together in the classic deployment mode by using a combination of the Azure Portal and PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: Connecting a virtual network to another virtual network (VNet-to-Vnet) is very similar to connecting a virtual network to an on-premises site location.
trans-unit.target: Connecting a virtual network to another virtual network (VNet-to-Vnet) is very similar to connecting a virtual network to an on-premises site location.

trans-unit.source: Both connectivity types use a VPN gateway to provide a secure tunnel using IPsec/IKE.
trans-unit.target: Both connectivity types use a VPN gateway to provide a secure tunnel using IPsec/IKE.

trans-unit.source: The VNets you connect can be in different subscriptions and different regions.
trans-unit.target: The VNets you connect can be in different subscriptions and different regions.

trans-unit.source: You can even combine VNet to VNet communication with multi-site configurations.
trans-unit.target: You can even combine VNet to VNet communication with multi-site configurations.

trans-unit.source: This lets you establish network topologies that combine cross-premises connectivity with inter-virtual network connectivity, as shown in the diagram below:
trans-unit.target: This lets you establish network topologies that combine cross-premises connectivity with inter-virtual network connectivity, as shown in the diagram below:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>VNet to VNet Connectivity Diagram</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>VNet to VNet Connectivity Diagram</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Azure currently has two deployment modes: the classic deployment mode, and the Azure Resource Manager deployment mode.
trans-unit.target: Azure currently has two deployment modes: the classic deployment mode, and the Azure Resource Manager deployment mode.

trans-unit.source: The configuration cmdlets and steps differ between deployment modes.
trans-unit.target: The configuration cmdlets and steps differ between deployment modes.

trans-unit.source: This topic will walk you through connecting virtual networks that are created using the classic deployment mode.
trans-unit.target: This topic will walk you through connecting virtual networks that are created using the classic deployment mode.

trans-unit.source: If you want to connect virtual networks together that were created in Azure Resource Manager mode, see <link><linkText>Configure a VNet-to-VNet connection using Azure Resource Manager and PowerShell</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: If you want to connect virtual networks together that were created in Azure Resource Manager mode, see <link><linkText>Configure a VNet-to-VNet connection using Azure Resource Manager and PowerShell</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: If you want to connect a virtual network that was created in the classic mode to a virtual network created in Azure Resource Manager, see <link><linkText>Connecting classic VNets to new VNets</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: If you want to connect a virtual network that was created in the classic mode to a virtual network created in Azure Resource Manager, see <link><linkText>Connecting classic VNets to new VNets</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Why connect virtual networks?
trans-unit.target: Why connect virtual networks?

trans-unit.source: You may want to connect virtual networks for the following reasons:
trans-unit.target: You may want to connect virtual networks for the following reasons:

trans-unit.source: Cross region geo-redundancy and geo-presence
trans-unit.target: Cross region geo-redundancy and geo-presence

trans-unit.source: You can set up your own geo-replication or synchronization with secure connectivity without going over internet-facing endpoints.
trans-unit.target: You can set up your own geo-replication or synchronization with secure connectivity without going over internet-facing endpoints.

trans-unit.source: With Azure Load Balancer and Microsoft or third-party clustering technology, you can setup highly available workload with geo-redundancy across multiple Azure regions.
trans-unit.target: With Azure Load Balancer and Microsoft or third-party clustering technology, you can setup highly available workload with geo-redundancy across multiple Azure regions.

trans-unit.source: One important example is to setup SQL Always On with Availability Groups spreading across multiple Azure regions.
trans-unit.target: One important example is to setup SQL Always On with Availability Groups spreading across multiple Azure regions.

trans-unit.source: Regional multi-tier applications with strong isolation boundary
trans-unit.target: Regional multi-tier applications with strong isolation boundary

trans-unit.source: Within the same region, you can setup multi-tier applications with multiple virtual networks connected together with strong isolation and secure inter-tier communication.
trans-unit.target: Within the same region, you can setup multi-tier applications with multiple virtual networks connected together with strong isolation and secure inter-tier communication.

trans-unit.source: Cross subscription, inter-organization communication in Azure
trans-unit.target: Cross subscription, inter-organization communication in Azure

trans-unit.source: If you have multiple Azure subscriptions, you can connect workloads from different subscriptions together securely between virtual networks.
trans-unit.target: If you have multiple Azure subscriptions, you can connect workloads from different subscriptions together securely between virtual networks.

trans-unit.source: For enterprises or service providers, you can enable cross organization communication with secure VPN technology within Azure.
trans-unit.target: For enterprises or service providers, you can enable cross organization communication with secure VPN technology within Azure.

trans-unit.source: VNet to VNet FAQ
trans-unit.target: VNet to VNet FAQ

trans-unit.source: The virtual networks can be in the same or different subscriptions.
trans-unit.target: The virtual networks can be in the same or different subscriptions.

trans-unit.source: The virtual networks can be in the same or different Azure regions (locations).
trans-unit.target: The virtual networks can be in the same or different Azure regions (locations).

trans-unit.source: A cloud service or a load balancing endpoint CANNOT span across virtual networks, even if they are connected together.
trans-unit.target: A cloud service or a load balancing endpoint CANNOT span across virtual networks, even if they are connected together.

trans-unit.source: Connecting multiple virtual networks together doesn't require any on-premises VPN gateways, unless cross-premises connectivity is required.
trans-unit.target: Connecting multiple virtual networks together doesn't require any on-premises VPN gateways, unless cross-premises connectivity is required.

trans-unit.source: VNet-to-VNet supports connecting Azure Virtual Networks.
trans-unit.target: VNet-to-VNet supports connecting Azure Virtual Networks.

trans-unit.source: It does not support connecting virtual machines or cloud services NOT in a virtual network.
trans-unit.target: It does not support connecting virtual machines or cloud services NOT in a virtual network.

trans-unit.source: VNet-to-VNet requires Azure VPN gateways with dynamic routing VPNs.
trans-unit.target: VNet-to-VNet requires Azure VPN gateways with dynamic routing VPNs.

trans-unit.source: Azure static routing VPN gateways are not supported.
trans-unit.target: Azure static routing VPN gateways are not supported.

trans-unit.source: Virtual network connectivity can be used simultaneously with multi-site VPNs, with a maximum of 10 VPN tunnels for a virtual network VPN gateway connecting to ether other virtual networks or on-premises sites.
trans-unit.target: Virtual network connectivity can be used simultaneously with multi-site VPNs, with a maximum of 10 VPN tunnels for a virtual network VPN gateway connecting to ether other virtual networks or on-premises sites.

trans-unit.source: The address spaces of the virtual networks and on-premises local network sites must not overlap.
trans-unit.target: The address spaces of the virtual networks and on-premises local network sites must not overlap.

trans-unit.source: Overlapping address spaces will cause the creation of virtual networks or uploading netcfg configuration files to fail.
trans-unit.target: Overlapping address spaces will cause the creation of virtual networks or uploading netcfg configuration files to fail.

trans-unit.source: Redundant tunnels between a pair of virtual networks are not supported.
trans-unit.target: Redundant tunnels between a pair of virtual networks are not supported.

trans-unit.source: All VPN tunnels of the virtual network, including P2S VPNs, share the available bandwidth on the Azure VPN gateway and the same VPN gateway uptime SLA in Azure.
trans-unit.target: All VPN tunnels of the virtual network, including P2S VPNs, share the available bandwidth on the Azure VPN gateway and the same VPN gateway uptime SLA in Azure.

trans-unit.source: VNet-to-VNet traffic travels across the Azure backbone.
trans-unit.target: VNet-to-VNet traffic travels across the Azure backbone.

trans-unit.source: Configure a VNet to VNet connection
trans-unit.target: Configure a VNet to VNet connection

trans-unit.source: In this procedure, we’ll walk you through connecting two virtual networks, VNet1 and VNet2.
trans-unit.target: In this procedure, we’ll walk you through connecting two virtual networks, VNet1 and VNet2.

trans-unit.source: You’ll need to be comfortable with networking in order to substitute the IP address ranges that are compatible with your network design requirements.
trans-unit.target: You’ll need to be comfortable with networking in order to substitute the IP address ranges that are compatible with your network design requirements.

trans-unit.source: From an Azure virtual network, connecting to another Azure virtual network is the same as connecting to an on premises network via site-to-site (S2S) VPN.
trans-unit.target: From an Azure virtual network, connecting to another Azure virtual network is the same as connecting to an on premises network via site-to-site (S2S) VPN.

trans-unit.source: This procedure primarily uses the Azure Portal, however, you must use Microsoft Azure PowerShell cmdlets to connect the VPN gateways.
trans-unit.target: This procedure primarily uses the Azure Portal, however, you must use Microsoft Azure PowerShell cmdlets to connect the VPN gateways.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Connecting VNet to VNet</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Connecting VNet to VNet</linkText>

trans-unit.source: There are 5 sections to plan and configure.
trans-unit.target: There are 5 sections to plan and configure.

trans-unit.source: Configure each section in the order listed below:
trans-unit.target: Configure each section in the order listed below:

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Plan your IP address ranges</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Plan your IP address ranges</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Create your virtual networks</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Create your virtual networks</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Add local networks</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Add local networks</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Create the dynamic routing gateways for each VNet</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Create the dynamic routing gateways for each VNet</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Connect the VPN gateways</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Connect the VPN gateways</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: Plan your IP address ranges
trans-unit.target: Plan your IP address ranges

trans-unit.source: It’s important to decide the ranges that you’ll use to configure your network configuration file (netcfg).
trans-unit.target: It’s important to decide the ranges that you’ll use to configure your network configuration file (netcfg).

trans-unit.source: From the perspective of VNet1, VNet2 is just another VPN connection that’s defined in the Azure platform.
trans-unit.target: From the perspective of VNet1, VNet2 is just another VPN connection that’s defined in the Azure platform.

trans-unit.source: And from VNet2, VNet1 is just another VPN connection.
trans-unit.target: And from VNet2, VNet1 is just another VPN connection.

trans-unit.source: They’ll both be identifying each other as a local network site.
trans-unit.target: They’ll both be identifying each other as a local network site.

trans-unit.source: Keep in mind that you must make sure that none of your VNet ranges or local network ranges overlap in any way.
trans-unit.target: Keep in mind that you must make sure that none of your VNet ranges or local network ranges overlap in any way.

trans-unit.source: Table 1 shows an example of how to define your VNets.
trans-unit.target: Table 1 shows an example of how to define your VNets.

trans-unit.source: Use the ranges below as a guideline only.
trans-unit.target: Use the ranges below as a guideline only.

trans-unit.source: Write down the ranges that you’ll be using for your virtual networks.
trans-unit.target: Write down the ranges that you’ll be using for your virtual networks.

trans-unit.source: You’ll need this information for later steps.
trans-unit.target: You’ll need this information for later steps.

trans-unit.source: Table 1
trans-unit.target: Table 1

trans-unit.source: Virtual Network
trans-unit.target: Virtual Network

trans-unit.source: Virtual Network Site Definition
trans-unit.target: Virtual Network Site Definition

trans-unit.source: Local Network Site Definition
trans-unit.target: Local Network Site Definition

trans-unit.source: VNet1
trans-unit.target: VNet1

trans-unit.source: VNet2
trans-unit.target: VNet2

trans-unit.source: Create your virtual networks
trans-unit.target: Create your virtual networks

trans-unit.source: For the purposes of this tutorial, we’ll create two virtual networks, VNet1 and VNet2.
trans-unit.target: For the purposes of this tutorial, we’ll create two virtual networks, VNet1 and VNet2.

trans-unit.source: Substitute your own values when creating your VNets.
trans-unit.target: Substitute your own values when creating your VNets.

trans-unit.source: For the purposes of this tutorial, we’ll use the following values for the VNets:
trans-unit.target: For the purposes of this tutorial, we’ll use the following values for the VNets:

trans-unit.source: VNet1: Address Space = 10.1.0.0/16; Region=US West
trans-unit.target: VNet1: Address Space = 10.1.0.0/16; Region=US West

trans-unit.source: VNet2: Address Space = 10.2.0.0/16; Region=Japan East
trans-unit.target: VNet2: Address Space = 10.2.0.0/16; Region=Japan East

trans-unit.source: Log in to the Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: Log in to the Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: In the lower left-hand corner of the screen, click New.
trans-unit.target: In the lower left-hand corner of the screen, click New.

trans-unit.source: In the navigation pane, click Network Services, and then click Virtual Network.
trans-unit.target: In the navigation pane, click Network Services, and then click Virtual Network.

trans-unit.source: Click Custom Create to begin the configuration wizard.
trans-unit.target: Click Custom Create to begin the configuration wizard.

trans-unit.source: On the Virtual Network Details page, enter the information below.
trans-unit.target: On the Virtual Network Details page, enter the information below.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Virtual Network Details</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Virtual Network Details</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Name - Name your virtual network.
trans-unit.target: Name - Name your virtual network.

trans-unit.source: For example, VNet1.
trans-unit.target: For example, VNet1.

trans-unit.source: Location – When you create a virtual network, you associate it with an Azure location (region).
trans-unit.target: Location – When you create a virtual network, you associate it with an Azure location (region).

trans-unit.source: For example, if you want your VMs that are deployed to your virtual network to be physically located in West US, select that location.
trans-unit.target: For example, if you want your VMs that are deployed to your virtual network to be physically located in West US, select that location.

trans-unit.source: You can’t change the location associated with your virtual network after you create it.
trans-unit.target: You can’t change the location associated with your virtual network after you create it.

trans-unit.source: On the DNS Servers and VPN Connectivity page, enter the following information, and then click the next arrow on the lower right.
trans-unit.target: On the DNS Servers and VPN Connectivity page, enter the following information, and then click the next arrow on the lower right.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>DNS Servers and VPN Connectivity</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>DNS Servers and VPN Connectivity</linkText>

trans-unit.source: DNS Servers - Enter the DNS server name and IP address, or select a previously registered DNS server from the dropdown.
trans-unit.target: DNS Servers - Enter the DNS server name and IP address, or select a previously registered DNS server from the dropdown.

trans-unit.source: This setting does not create a DNS server, it allows you to specify the DNS servers that you want to use for name resolution for this virtual network.
trans-unit.target: This setting does not create a DNS server, it allows you to specify the DNS servers that you want to use for name resolution for this virtual network.

trans-unit.source: If you want to have name resolution between your virtual networks, you’ll have to configure your own DNS server, rather than using the name resolution that is provided by Azure.
trans-unit.target: If you want to have name resolution between your virtual networks, you’ll have to configure your own DNS server, rather than using the name resolution that is provided by Azure.

trans-unit.source: Don’t select any of the checkboxes.
trans-unit.target: Don’t select any of the checkboxes.

trans-unit.source: Just click the arrow on the lower right to move to the next screen.
trans-unit.target: Just click the arrow on the lower right to move to the next screen.

trans-unit.source: On the Virtual Network Address Spaces page, specify the address range that you want to use for your virtual network.
trans-unit.target: On the Virtual Network Address Spaces page, specify the address range that you want to use for your virtual network.

trans-unit.source: These are the dynamic IP addresses (DIPS) that will be assigned to the VMs and other role instances that you deploy to this virtual network.
trans-unit.target: These are the dynamic IP addresses (DIPS) that will be assigned to the VMs and other role instances that you deploy to this virtual network.

trans-unit.source: It’s especially important to select a range that does not overlap with any of the ranges that are used for your on-premises network.
trans-unit.target: It’s especially important to select a range that does not overlap with any of the ranges that are used for your on-premises network.

trans-unit.source: You’ll need to coordinate with your network administrator, who may need to carve out a range of IP addresses from your on-premises network address space for you to use for your virtual network.
trans-unit.target: You’ll need to coordinate with your network administrator, who may need to carve out a range of IP addresses from your on-premises network address space for you to use for your virtual network.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Virtual Network Address Spaces page</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Virtual Network Address Spaces page</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Enter the following information, and then click the checkmark on the lower right to configure your network.
trans-unit.target: Enter the following information, and then click the checkmark on the lower right to configure your network.

trans-unit.source: Address Space - including Starting IP and Address Count.
trans-unit.target: Address Space - including Starting IP and Address Count.

trans-unit.source: Verify that the address spaces you specify don’t overlap any of the address spaces that you have on your on-premises network.
trans-unit.target: Verify that the address spaces you specify don’t overlap any of the address spaces that you have on your on-premises network.

trans-unit.source: For this example, we’ll use 10.1.0.0/16 for VNet1.
trans-unit.target: For this example, we’ll use 10.1.0.0/16 for VNet1.

trans-unit.source: Add subnet - including Starting IP and Address Count.
trans-unit.target: Add subnet - including Starting IP and Address Count.

trans-unit.source: Additional subnets are not required, but you may want to create a separate subnet for VMs that will have static DIPS.
trans-unit.target: Additional subnets are not required, but you may want to create a separate subnet for VMs that will have static DIPS.

trans-unit.source: Or you might want to have your VMs in a subnet that is separate from your other role instances.
trans-unit.target: Or you might want to have your VMs in a subnet that is separate from your other role instances.

trans-unit.source: Click the checkmark on the lower right of the page and your virtual network will begin to create.
trans-unit.target: Click the checkmark on the lower right of the page and your virtual network will begin to create.

trans-unit.source: When it completes, you will see Created listed under Status on the Networks page in the Azure Portal.
trans-unit.target: When it completes, you will see Created listed under Status on the Networks page in the Azure Portal.

trans-unit.source: Create another virtual network
trans-unit.target: Create another virtual network

trans-unit.source: Next, repeat the preceding steps to create another virtual network.
trans-unit.target: Next, repeat the preceding steps to create another virtual network.

trans-unit.source: In this exercise, you'll later connect these two virtual networks.
trans-unit.target: In this exercise, you'll later connect these two virtual networks.

trans-unit.source: Note that it's very important not to have duplicate or overlapping address spaces.
trans-unit.target: Note that it's very important not to have duplicate or overlapping address spaces.

trans-unit.source: For the purposes of this tutorial, use these values:
trans-unit.target: For the purposes of this tutorial, use these values:

trans-unit.source: VNet2
trans-unit.target: VNet2

trans-unit.source: Address Space = 10.2.0.0/16
trans-unit.target: Address Space = 10.2.0.0/16

trans-unit.source: Region = Japan East
trans-unit.target: Region = Japan East

trans-unit.source: Add local networks
trans-unit.target: Add local networks

trans-unit.source: When you create a VNet-to-VNet configuration, you need to configure each VNet to identify each other as a local network site.
trans-unit.target: When you create a VNet-to-VNet configuration, you need to configure each VNet to identify each other as a local network site.

trans-unit.source: In this procedure, you’ll configure each VNet as a local network.
trans-unit.target: In this procedure, you’ll configure each VNet as a local network.

trans-unit.source: If you already have previously configured VNets, this is how you would add them as local networks in the Azure Portal.
trans-unit.target: If you already have previously configured VNets, this is how you would add them as local networks in the Azure Portal.

trans-unit.source: In the lower left-hand corner of the screen, click New.
trans-unit.target: In the lower left-hand corner of the screen, click New.

trans-unit.source: In the navigation pane, click Network Services, and then click Virtual Network.
trans-unit.target: In the navigation pane, click Network Services, and then click Virtual Network.

trans-unit.source: Click Add Local Network
trans-unit.target: Click Add Local Network

trans-unit.source: On the Specify your local network details page, for Name, enter the name of a virtual network that you want to use in your VNet-to-VNet configuration.
trans-unit.target: On the Specify your local network details page, for Name, enter the name of a virtual network that you want to use in your VNet-to-VNet configuration.

trans-unit.source: For this example, we’ll use VNet 1, as we’ll be pointing VNet2 to this virtual network for our configuration.
trans-unit.target: For this example, we’ll use VNet 1, as we’ll be pointing VNet2 to this virtual network for our configuration.

trans-unit.source: For VPN Device IP Address, use any IP address.
trans-unit.target: For VPN Device IP Address, use any IP address.

trans-unit.source: Typically, you’d use the actual external IP address for a VPN device.
trans-unit.target: Typically, you’d use the actual external IP address for a VPN device.

trans-unit.source: For VNet-to-VNet configurations, you will use the Gateway IP address.
trans-unit.target: For VNet-to-VNet configurations, you will use the Gateway IP address.

trans-unit.source: But, given that you’ve not created the gateway yet, we use the IP address that you specify here as a placeholder.
trans-unit.target: But, given that you’ve not created the gateway yet, we use the IP address that you specify here as a placeholder.

trans-unit.source: You will then go back into these settings and configure them with the corresponding gateway IP addresses once Azure generates it.
trans-unit.target: You will then go back into these settings and configure them with the corresponding gateway IP addresses once Azure generates it.

trans-unit.source: On the Specify the address page, you will put in the actual IP address range and address count for VNet1.
trans-unit.target: On the Specify the address page, you will put in the actual IP address range and address count for VNet1.

trans-unit.source: This must correspond exactly to the range that you specified earlier for VNet1.
trans-unit.target: This must correspond exactly to the range that you specified earlier for VNet1.

trans-unit.source: After configuring VNet1 as a local network, go back and configure VNet2 using the values that correspond to that VNet.
trans-unit.target: After configuring VNet1 as a local network, go back and configure VNet2 using the values that correspond to that VNet.

trans-unit.source: Now you’ll point each VNet to the other as a local network.
trans-unit.target: Now you’ll point each VNet to the other as a local network.

trans-unit.source: In the Management Portal, go to the Configure page for VNet1.
trans-unit.target: In the Management Portal, go to the Configure page for VNet1.

trans-unit.source: Under site-to-site connectivity, select Connect to the local network, then select VNET2 as the local network.
trans-unit.target: Under site-to-site connectivity, select Connect to the local network, then select VNET2 as the local network.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Connect to local network</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Connect to local network</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the virtual network address spaces section on the same page, click add gateway subnet, then click the save icon at the bottom of the page to save your configuration.
trans-unit.target: In the virtual network address spaces section on the same page, click add gateway subnet, then click the save icon at the bottom of the page to save your configuration.

trans-unit.source: Repeat the step for VNet2 to specify VNet1 as a local network.
trans-unit.target: Repeat the step for VNet2 to specify VNet1 as a local network.

trans-unit.source: Create the dynamic routing gateways for each VNet
trans-unit.target: Create the dynamic routing gateways for each VNet

trans-unit.source: Now that you have each VNet configured, you’ll configure your VNet gateways.
trans-unit.target: Now that you have each VNet configured, you’ll configure your VNet gateways.

trans-unit.source: On the Networks page, verify that the status column for your virtual network is Created.
trans-unit.target: On the Networks page, verify that the status column for your virtual network is Created.

trans-unit.source: In the Name column, click the name of your virtual network.
trans-unit.target: In the Name column, click the name of your virtual network.

trans-unit.source: On the Dashboard page, notice that this VNet doesn’t have a gateway configured yet.
trans-unit.target: On the Dashboard page, notice that this VNet doesn’t have a gateway configured yet.

trans-unit.source: You’ll see this status change as you go through the steps to configure your gateway.
trans-unit.target: You’ll see this status change as you go through the steps to configure your gateway.

trans-unit.source: At the bottom of the page, click Create Gateway.
trans-unit.target: At the bottom of the page, click Create Gateway.

trans-unit.source: You must select Dynamic Routing.
trans-unit.target: You must select Dynamic Routing.

trans-unit.source: When the system prompts you to confirm that you want the gateway created, click Yes.
trans-unit.target: When the system prompts you to confirm that you want the gateway created, click Yes.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Gateway type</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Gateway type</linkText>

trans-unit.source: When your gateway is creating, notice the gateway graphic on the page changes to yellow and says Creating Gateway.
trans-unit.target: When your gateway is creating, notice the gateway graphic on the page changes to yellow and says Creating Gateway.

trans-unit.source: It typically takes about 15 minutes for the gateway to create.
trans-unit.target: It typically takes about 15 minutes for the gateway to create.

trans-unit.source: Repeat the same steps for your other VNet, being sure to select Dynamic Gateway.
trans-unit.target: Repeat the same steps for your other VNet, being sure to select Dynamic Gateway.

trans-unit.source: You don’t need the first VNet gateway to complete before you begin to create the gateway for your other VNet.
trans-unit.target: You don’t need the first VNet gateway to complete before you begin to create the gateway for your other VNet.

trans-unit.source: When the gateway status changes to Connecting, the IP address for each gateway will be visible in the Dashboard.
trans-unit.target: When the gateway status changes to Connecting, the IP address for each gateway will be visible in the Dashboard.

trans-unit.source: Write down the IP address that corresponds to each VNet, taking care not to mix them up.
trans-unit.target: Write down the IP address that corresponds to each VNet, taking care not to mix them up.

trans-unit.source: These are the IP addresses that will be used when you edit your placeholder IP addresses for the VPN Device in Local Networks.
trans-unit.target: These are the IP addresses that will be used when you edit your placeholder IP addresses for the VPN Device in Local Networks.

trans-unit.source: Edit the local network
trans-unit.target: Edit the local network

trans-unit.source: On the Local Networks page, click the name of the Local Network name that you want to edit, then click Edit at the bottom of the page.
trans-unit.target: On the Local Networks page, click the name of the Local Network name that you want to edit, then click Edit at the bottom of the page.

trans-unit.source: For VPN Device IP address, input the IP address of the gateway that corresponds to the VNet.
trans-unit.target: For VPN Device IP address, input the IP address of the gateway that corresponds to the VNet.

trans-unit.source: For example, for VNet1, put in the gateway IP address assigned to VNet1.
trans-unit.target: For example, for VNet1, put in the gateway IP address assigned to VNet1.

trans-unit.source: Then click the arrow at the bottom of the page.
trans-unit.target: Then click the arrow at the bottom of the page.

trans-unit.source: On the Specify the address space page, click the checkmark on the lower right without making any changes.
trans-unit.target: On the Specify the address space page, click the checkmark on the lower right without making any changes.

trans-unit.source: Connect the VPN gateways
trans-unit.target: Connect the VPN gateways

trans-unit.source: When all of the previous steps have been completed, you’ll set the IPsec/IKE pre-shared keys to be the same.
trans-unit.target: When all of the previous steps have been completed, you’ll set the IPsec/IKE pre-shared keys to be the same.

trans-unit.source: You can do this either using a REST API, or PowerShell cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: You can do this either using a REST API, or PowerShell cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: If you use PowerShell, verify that you have the latest version of the Microsoft Azure PowerShell cmdlets.
trans-unit.target: If you use PowerShell, verify that you have the latest version of the Microsoft Azure PowerShell cmdlets.

trans-unit.source: The examples below use PowerShell cmdlets to set the key value to A1b2C3D4.
trans-unit.target: The examples below use PowerShell cmdlets to set the key value to A1b2C3D4.

trans-unit.source: Note that both use the same key value.
trans-unit.target: Note that both use the same key value.

trans-unit.source: Edit the examples below to reflect your own values.
trans-unit.target: Edit the examples below to reflect your own values.

trans-unit.source: For VNet1
trans-unit.target: For VNet1

trans-unit.source: For VNet2
trans-unit.target: For VNet2

trans-unit.source: Wait for the connections to initialize.
trans-unit.target: Wait for the connections to initialize.

trans-unit.source: Once the gateway has initialized, the gateway will look like the graphic below and your virtual networks are connected.
trans-unit.target: Once the gateway has initialized, the gateway will look like the graphic below and your virtual networks are connected.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Gateway Status - Connected</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Gateway Status - Connected</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Next Steps
trans-unit.target: Next Steps

trans-unit.source: If you want to add virtual machines to your virtual network, see <link><linkText>How to Create a Custom Virtual Machine</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: If you want to add virtual machines to your virtual network, see <link><linkText>How to Create a Custom Virtual Machine</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: If you want to configure a VNet connection using RRAS, see <link><linkText>Configure a Site-to-Site VPN using Windows Server 2012 Routing and Remote Access Service (RRAS)</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: If you want to configure a VNet connection using RRAS, see <link><linkText>Configure a Site-to-Site VPN using Windows Server 2012 Routing and Remote Access Service (RRAS)</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: For information about the configuration schema, see <link><linkText>Azure Virtual Network Configuration Schema</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For information about the configuration schema, see <link><linkText>Azure Virtual Network Configuration Schema</linkText><title></title></link>.
